00017 =head1 NAME
00018 
00019 parserFunction.pl - An easy way of adding new functions to the current context.
00020 
00021 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00022 
00023 This file implements an easy way of creating new functions that
00024 are added to the current Parser context.  (This avoids having to
00025 do the complicated procedure outlined in the docs/parser/extensions
00026 samples.)
00027 
00028 To create a function that can be used in Formula() calls (and by
00029 students in their answers), use the parserFunction() routine, as
00030 in the following examples:
00031 
00032     parserFunction(f => "sqrt(x+1)-2");
00033 
00034     $x = Formula('x');
00035     parserFunction(f => sqrt($x+1)-2);
00036 
00037     parserFunction("f(x)" => "sqrt(x+1)-2");
00038 
00039     parserFunction("f(x,y)" => "sqrt(x*y)");
00040 
00041 The first parameter to parserFunction is the name of the function
00042 or the name with its argument list.  In the first case, the
00043 names of the variables are taken from the formula for the
00044 function, and are listed in alphabetical order.
00045 
00046 The second argument is the formula used to compute the value
00047 of the function.  It can be either a string or a Parser Formula
00048 object.
00049 
00050 =cut
00051 
00052 loadMacros('MathObjects.pl');
00053 
00054 sub _parserFunction_init {parserFunction::Init()}; # don't reload this file
00055 #
00056 #  The package that will manage user-defined functions
00057 #
00058 package parserFunction;
00059 our @ISA = qw(Parser::Function);
00060 
00061 sub Init {
00062   main::PG_restricted_eval('sub parserFunction {parserFunction->Create(@_)}');
00063 }
00064 
00065 sub Create {
00066   my $self = shift; my $name = shift; my $formula = shift;
00067   my $context = (Value::isContext($_[0]) ? shift : Value->context);
00068   my @argNames; my @argTypes; my @newVars;
00069   #
00070   #  Look for argument names for the function
00071   #   (check that the arguments are ok, and temporarily
00072   #    add in any variables that are not already there)
00073   #
00074   if ($name =~ m/^([a-z0-9]+)\(\s*(.*?)\s*\)$/i) {
00075     $name = $1; my $args = $2;
00076     @argNames = split(/\s*,\s*/,$args);
00077     foreach my $x (@argNames) {
00078       Value::Error("Illegal variable name '%s'",$x) if $x =~ m/[^a-z]/i;
00079       unless ($context->{variables}{$x}) {
00080     $context->variables->add($x=>'Real');
00081     push(@newVars,$x);
00082       }
00083     }
00084   } else {
00085     Value::Error("Illegal function name '%s'",$name)
00086       if $name =~ m/[^a-z0-9]/i;
00087   }
00088   #
00089   #  Create the formula and get its arguments and types
00090   #
00091   $formula = $context->Package("Formula")->new($context,$formula) unless Value::isFormula($formula);
00092   @argNames = main::lex_sort(keys(%{$formula->{variables}})) unless scalar(@argNames);
00093   foreach my $x (@argNames) {push(@argTypes,$context->{variables}{$x}{type})}
00094   #
00095   #  Add the function to the context and create the perl function
00096   #
00097   $context->functions->add(
00098     $name => {
00099       (length($name) == 1? (TeX=>$name): ()),
00100       @_, class => 'parserFunction', argCount => scalar(@argNames),
00101       argNames => [@argNames], argTypes => [@argTypes],
00102       function => $formula->perlFunction(undef,[@argNames]),
00103       formula => $formula, type => $formula->typeRef,
00104     }
00105   );
00106   main::PG_restricted_eval("sub main::$name {Parser::Function->call('$name',\@_)}");
00107   $context->variables->remove(@newVars) if scalar(@newVars);
00108 }
00109 
00110 #
00111 #  Check that there are the right number of arguments
00112 #  and they are of the right type.
00113 #
00114 sub _check {
00115   my $self = shift; my $name = $self->{name};
00116   return if $self->checkArgCount($self->{def}{argCount});
00117   my @argTypes = @{$self->{def}{argTypes}}; my $n = 0;
00118   foreach my $x (@{$self->{params}}) {
00119     my $atype = shift(@argTypes); $n++;
00120     $self->Error("The %s argument for '%s' should be of type %s",
00121          NameForNumber($n),$name,$atype->{name})
00122       unless (Parser::Item::typeMatch($atype,$x->{type}));
00123   }
00124   $self->{type} = $self->{def}{type};
00125 }
00126 
00127 #
00128 #  Call the function stored in the definition
00129 #
00130 sub _eval {
00131   my $self = shift; my $name = $self->{name};
00132   &{$self->{def}{function}}(@_);
00133 }
00134 
00135 #
00136 #  Check the arguments and compute the result.
00137 #
00138 sub _call {
00139   my $self = shift; my $name = shift;
00140   my $def = Value->context->{functions}{$name};
00141   &{$def->{function}}(@_);
00142 }
00143 
00144 =head2 ($Function)->D
00145 
00146  #
00147  #  Compute the derivative of (single-variable) functions
00148  #    using the chain rule.
00149  #
00150 
00151 =cut
00152 
00153 sub D {
00154   my $self = shift; my $def = $self->{def};
00155   $self->Error("Can't differentiate function '%s'",$self->{name})
00156     unless $def->{argCount} == 1;
00157   my $x = $def->{argNames}[0];
00158   my $Df = $def->{formula}->D($x);
00159   my $g = $self->{params}[0];
00160   return (($Df->substitute($x=>$g))*($g->D(@_)))->{tree}->reduce;
00161 }
00162 
00163 =head3 NameForNumber($number)
00164 
00165 #
00166 #  Get the name for a number
00167 #
00168 
00169 =cut
00170 
00171 sub NameForNumber {
00172   my $n = shift;
00173   my $name =  ('zeroth','first','second','third','fourth','fifth',
00174                'sixth','seventh','eighth','ninth','tenth')[$n];
00175   $name = "$n-th" if ($n > 10);
00176   return $name;
00177 }
